Award.AwardTitle: Dialect Evolution and Ongoing Variable Linguistic Input: Production and Perception of the English spoken in the Pacific Northwest

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Northwestern United States (including Washington state) is the product of a rich history of Native American, European, Asian, and other influences. The Pacific Northwest English (PNWE) project explores the extent of English dialect mixture and development in this region. The story of the Pacific Northwest is one of constant settlement and immigration. Although a few pockets of historically-isolated communities can be found, most Northwesterners live in places where their voices intermingle with people of different backgrounds.

Two hundred years after Lewis and Clark's historic voyage to the Pacific coast, researchers at the University of Washington ask: has the Northwest been established long enough to have unique dialect features? Has the history of ongoing settlement made it the truest of American melting-pots? How much has contact between Native-Americans, African-Americans, Mexican-Americans and Anglo-Americans shaped the speech of this region?

This project examines the way Washingtonians speak, and explores how listeners (from the PNW and elsewhere) react to PNWE speech. Speech data will be collected from Washington-born subjects in both rural and urban parts of the state. Data from three generations of speakers allows examination of the progression of change over time. This study employs quantitative Sociophonetic methods that allow measurement of the acoustic signal produced when we speak. Of particular interest are a set of sound changes that appear to be focused in PNWE, including one in which vowels such as appear in the words BEG and BAG are both shifting in this variety of English to rhyme with the vowel in BAKE. This type of change captures a subtle but important aspect of linguistic change. Though speakers in this region do not hear themselves producing these differences, such differences mark their speech, and are "big" enough differences to confuse listeners from other regions. This type of phenomenon is of interest to linguists, because it sheds light on how languages change, and on long it takes for language change to take place, all below the level of human consciousness.

The Broader Impacts are varied and strong. Student researchers will gain valuable experience in sociolinguistic fieldwork and the scientific analysis of language variation. The researchers will be drawn from a wide range of ethnic minorities, including native Americans, which have been underrepresented in linguistic research. There is considerable interest among the general community in the topic of varieties of English in the local area. Oral histories and sound clips from speakers from the region, as well as other data, will be included in a website freely available for public access.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the "English in the Pacific Northwest" study was to address the following primary research questions: Has the dialect of English spoken in the American Pacific Northwest (PNWE hereafter) been established long enough to have unique features?  Are these dialect features able to be detected by Washington speakers?

 The PNWE study examined the way Washingtonians speak, and explored how listeners react to PNWE speech. Audio-recordings targetting specific features of the vowel system were gathered from more than 100 Washington-born speakers in both rural and urban parts of the state. Data from three generations of speakers allowed us to examine the progression of language change over time. Of particular interest are a set of sound changes that appear to be focused in PNWE and the American West more generally, including one change in which vowels such as those appearing in the words BEG and BAG are shifting to rhyme with the vowel in BAKE, and another change in which the vowels in CAUGHT and COT have been collapsed on most spectral dimensions, so that they are homophonous. Significant differences in the BEG~BAKE~BAG vowels, sufficient to distinguish them from the pronunciations used in other parts of the Northern, Eastern and Southern United States, were found. For some speakers, small differences in the low-frequency Hertz range (first formant) of the vowel remained to keep the vowels separate. The evidence for these differences emerges robustly from acoustic measurements of the time-varying spectral shape of the vowel. Generational data suggest that this change is not new, however, but has been established in this region for some time. A listening test examined the ability of listeners to hear the subtle first formant acoustic differences in these vowels. The question was whether the auditory system can be "trained" to use a very small acoustic difference, where this small difference is potentially large enough to support a linguistic distinction that is in the process of being lost. The study found that listeners could not hear a difference between acoustically-distinct tokens of BAG and BAKE when these words were presented alone. They were only able to correctly identify these words when other words were present to help disambiguate their meanings, such as "BAKE A PIE." So, it appears this small first-formant difference is not used by the Washingtonian ear.  This type of change captures a subtle but important aspect of linguistic change. Though speakers in this region do not hear themselves producing these differences, and do not perceive themselves as having an "accent," these differences mark their speech. 

We also explored issues of perceived rootedness in the Pacific Northwest, and how social embedding in the region intersects with issues of ethnic affiliation.  Washingtonians of five different ethnicities were included in the research. We found that social network structure, experience of cultural phenomena such as internment (for our Japanese-American respondents), reservation life (for our Yakama respondents), and urban growth (for our African-American, Mexican-American and Caucasian-American respondents), all affect their sense of rootedness in the Pacific Northwest.  In other words, ethnic affiliation alone did not predict vowel system features.  Social network was a better predictor. All of these types of factors impact language variation and change.  Our Japanese-American respondents most frequently reported a sense of being authentically Pacific Northwest and, more than other groups, showed high levels of social network integration into ethnically-diverse neighborhoods. This ethnic group was highly advanced in the PNWE vowel system changes. However, other groups showed both ethnolectal and regional features. For example, the African-American respondents' speech reflected both African-American English and the Pacific Northwest changes. This research shows a clear link between language change and socio-historical factors.   This link is of interest to Sociolinguists, because it sheds light on how languages change, and on how long it takes for language change to take place, all below the level of human consciousness.  This research has been covered over the last several years in several local news outlets, including: KUOW radio, KPLU/KNKX radio, King5 TV, the Seattle PI, and KIRO-TV.
